p: Note that each of these scenarios—unemployment, income, housing, education, health care—involves synergies between biological and social processes at the population level. They hint at how overlapping epidemics may not merely co‐occur but rather interact to make matters worse. Much of the media commentary has focused on how comorbidities like hypertension and diabetes increase the risk of COVID‐19 becoming deadly. Syndemic theory alerts us, in addition, to the possibility that the pandemic could intensify racial inequities in the social and economic conditions that increase risk for hypertension and diabetes to begin with, exacerbating the toll those diseases already take on Black people and communities. The possibility of such synergistic effects—over the short and long term—underscores the relevance of syndemic thinking.
